articles.headline: Conservative Elite in Capital Pay Heed to Ryan as Thinker
articles.snippet: Since his emergence as the key Congressional Republican on the budget issue, Representative Paul D. Ryan has had a powerful influence on intellectuals, writers and policy makers.
articles.abstract: Since his emergence as the key Congressional Republican on the budget issue, Representative Paul D. Ryan has had a powerful influence on intellectuals, writers and policy makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the debate over the federal deficit roiling last year, David Smick, a financial market consultant, held a dinner for a bipartisan group of connected budget thinkers at his expansive home here.

articles.headline: Caterpillar Workers Ratify Deal They Dislike
articles.snippet: The showdown was a test case in American labor relations, partly because Caterpillar was driving such a hard bargain when its business was thriving.
articles.abstract: The showdown was a test case in American labor relations, partly because Caterpillar was driving such a hard bargain when its business was thriving.
articles.lead_paragraph: Workers who had been striking at a Caterpillar hydraulic parts factory in Joliet, Ill., voted on Friday to ratify a proposed six-year contract that contained almost all of the concessions the company had demanded.

articles.headline: The Auto Insurance Case That Blew Up on the Internet
articles.snippet: The auto insurer Progressive may have done everything wrong in a lawsuit that became a cause célèbre on social media this week, but there’s a lesson for us all in the details.
articles.abstract: The auto insurer Progressive may have done everything wrong in a lawsuit that became a cause célèbre on social media this week, but there’s a lesson for us all in the details.
articles.lead_paragraph: It isn’t often that automobile insurance becomes the subject of nationwide outrage. So when it does happen, it’s worth a peek inside all our policies to figure out how they actually work and what the insurance companies are up to behind the scenes.

articles.headline: Panic Seizes India as a Region’s Strife Radiates
articles.snippet: What began as a vicious if obscure fight over land and power between Muslims and an indigenous tribe in a remote state has set off panic among northeastern migrants across India.
articles.abstract: What began as a vicious if obscure fight over land and power between Muslims and an indigenous tribe in a remote state has set off panic among northeastern migrants across India.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRAJAKHAL, India — Like a fever, fear has spread across India this week, from big cities like Bangalore to smaller places like Mysore, a contagion fueling a message: Run. Head home. Flee. And that is what thousands of migrants from the country’s distant northeastern states are doing, jamming into train stations in an exodus challenging the Indian ideals of tolerance and diversity.

articles.headline: Deutsche Bank’s Business With Sanctioned Nations Under Scrutiny
articles.snippet: A clash between New York’s top banking regulator and federal authorities over how to handle a similar case against Standard Chartered could complicate the current investigation.
articles.abstract: A clash between New York’s top banking regulator and federal authorities over how to handle a similar case against Standard Chartered could complicate the current investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal and state prosecutors are investigating Deutsche Bank and several other global banks over accusations that they funneled billions of dollars through their American branches for Iran, Sudan and other sanctioned nations, according to law enforcement officials with knowledge of the cases.

articles.headline: Obama Lags on Judicial Picks, Limiting His Mark on Courts
articles.snippet: With relatively few lower-court appointments, President Obama has made less of an ideological imprint on the judiciary than liberals hoped and conservatives feared.
articles.abstract: With relatively few lower-court appointments, President Obama has made less of an ideological imprint on the judiciary than liberals hoped and conservatives feared.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is set to end his term with dozens fewer lower-court appointments than both Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush achieved in their first four years, and probably with less of a lasting ideological imprint on the judiciary than many liberals had hoped for and conservatives had feared.

articles.headline: Merchants and Shoppers Sour on Daily Deal Sites
articles.snippet: After an initial flush of enthusiasm, merchants have grown wary of daily deal Web sites like Groupon and LivingSocial. Now consumers are starting to follow.
articles.abstract: After an initial flush of enthusiasm, merchants have grown wary of daily deal Web sites like Groupon and LivingSocial. Now consumers are starting to follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: As their e-mail in-boxes filled with daily deal offers from Web sites like Groupon, Lea Pische and Edwin Hermawan, a pizzeria waitress and a former lawyer living on the Lower East Side, finally decided to buy one: a discounted Skillshare class on how to start a business.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: The Sun Hasn’t Set on the Drive-In
articles.snippet: Though far from their 1950s golden era, some drive-in theaters are going strong. Movie lovers are drawn by the low-cost tickets and an outdoor liveliness that multiplexes can’t match.
articles.abstract: Though far from their 1950s golden era, some drive-in theaters are going strong. Movie lovers are drawn by the low-cost tickets and an outdoor liveliness that multiplexes can’t match.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, Calif.

articles.headline: Lawyers From Suits Against Big Tobacco Target Food Makers
articles.snippet: More than a dozen lawyers who took on Big Tobacco have filed 25 cases asserting that manufacturers like ConAgra Foods and PepsiCo are misleading consumers and violating federal law.
articles.abstract: More than a dozen lawyers who took on Big Tobacco have filed 25 cases asserting that manufacturers like ConAgra Foods and PepsiCo are misleading consumers and violating federal law.
articles.lead_paragraph: Don Barrett, a Mississippi lawyer, took in hundreds of millions of dollars a decade ago after suing Big Tobacco and winning record settlements from R. J. Reynolds, Philip Morris and other cigarette makers. So did Walter Umphrey, Dewitt M. Lovelace and Stuart and Carol Nelkin.

articles.headline: Goldman, Still Playing in Bayou’s Mud
articles.snippet: On the day it paid $20.7 million to Bayou hedge fund investors, Goldman Sachs filed to get the same amount back from Bayou as a creditor.
articles.abstract: On the day it paid $20.7 million to Bayou hedge fund investors, Goldman Sachs filed to get the same amount back from Bayou as a creditor.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE story of the Bayou Group, the hedge fund firm that collapsed in a whirl of lies and drugs, was always a little weird. But it just keeps getting weirder.

articles.headline: Secret E-Scores Chart Consumers’ Buying Power
articles.snippet: Buying-power scores, compiled from huge amounts of data, measure your potential value as a customer. But you’ll probably never learn your total.
articles.abstract: Buying-power scores, compiled from huge amounts of data, measure your potential value as a customer. But you’ll probably never learn your total.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. CLOUD, Minn.

articles.headline: U.S. Says Iraqis Are Helping Iran to Skirt Sanctions
articles.snippet: Financial institutions and oil-smuggling operations in Iraq have given Iran a crucial flow of dollars as sanctions over its nuclear work squeeze its economy, officials and experts said.
articles.abstract: Financial institutions and oil-smuggling operations in Iraq have given Iran a crucial flow of dollars as sanctions over its nuclear work squeeze its economy, officials and experts said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama announced last month that he was barring a Baghdad bank from any dealings with the American banking system, it was a rare acknowledgment of a delicate problem facing the administration in a country that American troops just left: for months, Iraq has been helping Iran skirt economic sanctions imposed on Tehran because of its nuclear program.
articles.byline: By James Risen and Duraid Adnan

articles.headline: Skilled Work, Without the Worker
articles.snippet: A new wave of robots is replacing workers in both manufacturing and distribution.
articles.abstract: A new wave of robots is replacing workers in both manufacturing and distribution.
articles.lead_paragraph: DRACHTEN, the Netherlands — At the Philips Electronics factory on the coast of China, hundreds of workers use their hands and specialized tools to assemble electric shavers. That is the old way.

articles.headline: Do Argentines Need Therapy? Pull Up a Couch
articles.snippet: The number of practicing psychologists in Argentina has been surging, making the country a world leader, at least when it comes to people’s broad willingness to bare their souls.
articles.abstract: The number of practicing psychologists in Argentina has been surging, making the country a world leader, at least when it comes to people’s broad willingness to bare their souls.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The cafe, just north of a leafy district affectionately nicknamed Villa Freud, was almost empty. Roberto Álvarez sipped his espresso, furrowed his brow and began ticking off the names of psychologists he had seen over the past decade. He stopped counting only when he noticed that he was running short of fingers.

articles.headline: Afghan Attacks on Allied Troops Prompt NATO to Shift Policy
articles.snippet: The military’s efforts to stop “insider attacks” are indications of how destabilizing the deaths of coalition troops at the hands of Afghan forces have become.
articles.abstract: The military’s efforts to stop “insider attacks” are indications of how destabilizing the deaths of coalition troops at the hands of Afghan forces have become.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After months of military leaders’ attempts to tamp down worries over the killings of American and NATO troops by the Afghan forces serving beside them, Gen. John R. Allen, the top commander in Afghanistan, called an urgent meeting of his generals last Wednesday to address the escalating death toll.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: The Courtship Before Romney Elevated Ryan
articles.snippet: A congenial meeting in 2007 led to closer collaboration, especially in the last 18 months, as the Republican Party shifted more to the right.
articles.abstract: A congenial meeting in 2007 led to closer collaboration, especially in the last 18 months, as the Republican Party shifted more to the right.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be a 15-minute courtesy visit from a Republican with big presidential aspirations to a rising star in Congress with big ideas about how to address the nation’s fiscal problems.

articles.headline: In Apple’s Patent Case, Tech Shifts May Follow
articles.snippet: If Apple prevails in its legal dogfight with Samsung over patents, experts believe its rivals will have a stronger incentive to distinguish their smartphone and tablet products.
articles.abstract: If Apple prevails in its legal dogfight with Samsung over patents, experts believe its rivals will have a stronger incentive to distinguish their smartphone and tablet products.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — This week, nine jurors are expected to hunker down in a federal courthouse here to decide a case that could change how the world’s smartphones and tablet computers look and work.

articles.headline: Tension Over Aid to Greece Could Unsettle Markets
articles.snippet: Greece’s prime minister, Antonis Samaras, is expected to seek an extension for meeting his country’s budgetary and reform commitments, but Germany appears reluctant to grant further concessions.
articles.abstract: Greece’s prime minister, Antonis Samaras, is expected to seek an extension for meeting his country’s budgetary and reform commitments, but Germany appears reluctant to grant further concessions.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — While the Greek prime minister, Antonis Samaras, will be greeted with military honors when he arrives in Berlin on Friday, his pleas for easier bailout terms could meet with a cool reception, setting up tension that could unsettle the financial markets this week.

articles.headline: Journalists Dancing on the Edge of Truth
articles.snippet: The Web’s ferocious appetite for content probably had something to do with why Jonah Lehrer, a popular science writer, has found himself at the center of a plagiarism scandal.
articles.abstract: The Web’s ferocious appetite for content probably had something to do with why Jonah Lehrer, a popular science writer, has found himself at the center of a plagiarism scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before writing this column on recent incidents of plagiarism and fabrication, I spent time on the Web reading all known thought on the subject, making notes as I went. When I wrote it up, I used those notes to help create something I am now claiming as my own. Yes, I made phone calls to relevant experts and did historical research, but in the main — columnists are in part human aggregators — everything written here reflects something that came before it.

articles.headline: A Studio-Theater Venture Aims to Fill Gaps
articles.snippet: Open Road Films is a joint venture between the nation’s two largest theater chains that was created to bridge the gap between those who distribute pictures and those who sell tickets.
articles.abstract: Open Road Films is a joint venture between the nation’s two largest theater chains that was created to bridge the gap between those who distribute pictures and those who sell tickets.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Studios make and release movies. Theater chains put them on screens.

articles.headline: Media Companies, Seeing Profit Slip, Push Into Education
articles.snippet: Under pressure to expand, media companies are capitalizing on the changes that technology is bringing to classrooms.
articles.abstract: Under pressure to expand, media companies are capitalizing on the changes that technology is bringing to classrooms.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As another academic year starts, about 500,000 children across the country will find themselves learning subjects like middle school history or high school biology from a new line of digital textbooks. These manuals, branded Techbooks, come with all the Internet frills: video, virtual labs, downloadable content.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Coming Next: Using an App as Prescribed
articles.snippet: Apps that can assess data like blood glucose levels, diet and drug regimen — and can be reimbursed by insurance — will soon be prescribed by doctors to help treat patients.
articles.abstract: Apps that can assess data like blood glucose levels, diet and drug regimen — and can be reimbursed by insurance — will soon be prescribed by doctors to help treat patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before long, your doctor may be telling you to download two apps and call her in the morning.

articles.headline: Cautious Moves on Foreclosures Haunting Obama
articles.snippet: President Obama’s response to the housing crisis was deliberately subdued, and some economists believe stronger action could have softened the economic impact.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s response to the housing crisis was deliberately subdued, and some economists believe stronger action could have softened the economic impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After inheriting the worst economic downturn since the Great Depression, President Obama poured vast amounts of money into efforts to stabilize the financial system, rescue the auto industry and revive the economy.

articles.headline: China Defers Death Penalty for Disgraced Official’s Wife
articles.snippet: Gu Kailai, the wife of Bo Xilai, received a suspended death sentence for the poisoning death of a British business associate. In the Chinese legal system, such a sentence is often commuted to life in prison.
articles.abstract: Gu Kailai, the wife of Bo Xilai, received a suspended death sentence for the poisoning death of a British business associate. In the Chinese legal system, such a sentence is often commuted to life in prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Chinese court on Monday handed Gu Kailai, the wife of a disgraced Communist Party leader, a suspended death sentence for killing a British business associate who she reportedly feared was plotting to harm her son. In the Chinese legal system, such a sentence is tantamount to life in prison.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Packaging Seeks to Reveal a Warm Romney
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney’s campaign has recruited professionals to manage his appearance at the Republican convention, hoping to overcome his image of being stiff and aloof.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney’s campaign has recruited professionals to manage his appearance at the Republican convention, hoping to overcome his image of being stiff and aloof.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — They hail from the Broadway stage, the control rooms of NBC and the design studios that created sleek sets for Oprah Winfrey and Jon Stewart.
